physDesc.p: The letter consists of two sheets of paper with typewriting on both sides of each. There are some areas where words are scratched out with pencil and pencil is added for corrections. There appears to be a watermark on the paper, but it is unreadable under the text.

editorialDecl.p: This letter contains references to the following:

body.p: Your letter of January 18th is here, and your generosity in regard to the matter of my poems gave me great pleasure. Neither Fletcher nor I have any desire to put in things which you people do not like and do not want. As I have written you several times, “Off the Turnpike” is definitely out of consideration. My contribution will now run: “Patterns,” “A Spring Day,” and “Stravinsky."

Your feeling about the onomatopoeic lines in the “Quartet” is unfortunate, as I am afraid I cannot change them and leave the poem the kind of thing it was meant to be. I was endeavouring to reproduce not only the movement, but as much as possible the sound, of the music; and the wheeze and bumps to which you so strongly object were to give the effect of the squealing pipes and the dissonance and jolt of the drums on another key. Read aloud, it does have this affect. I suppose it is veristic, if you like, but I am afraid it is quite impossible for me to confine myself within the strict Imagist tenets originally set down by Ezra. You remember that last year, when we severed our connection with Ezra, we decided to become broader, and we have certainly done so. In the main, I think Fletcher and I both agree with your interpretation of Imagism, but we are both intensely dramatic in our work, and I think both of us are willing to sacrifice some of the more astringent Imagistic rules for the sake of vividness and life. I think we should, within reason, allow such variations of type, as I am sure it tends to make the movement more interesting, not only to the public, but in itself as art, and I feel sure that there is in Imagism something very vital and real, which can withstand differences and yet remain itself. But I think that your contention that the Anthology should be kept to the more perfectly Imagistic type, as much as we can do so without restraining ourselves too much, is right, and I trust that you will forgive me, therefore, if I leave in the onomatopoeic lines, realizing of course that in general your contention is just.

Your book has just come, and I am perfectly delighted with it. I think those coloured wood-cuts that Monro puts on his books are most attractive, and I only wish that I could have a book come out in that way. I am afraid I am going to have a very bad time with the “French Poets” in England, judging from the snippy notice in the “Times.” This is not the moment for American authors to publish in England. It is too bad that our shilly-shallying Democratic government has lost us all our friends in Europe. For those of us who are heart and soul in favour of the Allied cause, the situation is not only annoying in the extreme but ludicrous. However, my remarks about toleration in one of my letters referred to the necessity of social intercourse, and not to my opinion, as I supposed you realized. I only hope you did realize it. I should so much regret any misunderstanding on that subject. The country is becoming extremely warlike, and the future, I think, will depend entirely on the results of the presidential election.

I am rather sorry I pitched into you so hard about cutting Flint’s review. I was very grateful to you for leaving that out about the champagne, etc., but what did annoy me was your feeling obliged to put in a “so far” where Flint said: “These are the best translations of the Symbolist poets;” and also, I was sorry that you left out the sentence about the reading of the book being El Dorado to anyone who did not know the poets in question. It seemed to me that “so far” would be naturally understood in the sentence. Everything one writes must necessarily be “so far;” there can never be a final judgment, and to insist upon it I thought was unfortunate. Of course, I know that both you and Flint are engaged in French translations. He is doing Varhaeren, I think, and I suppose you will have many in your Remy de Gourmont book. Then if you beat me in translating, well and good. So be it. We can only all do our best, and who beats the other does not really matter at all, as we are a group and all working together for the same ends.

To go back to your book, I don’t wonder it sold so many copies. It is appetizing to look at, and it is excellent reading. You know what I think of these poems, and in reading the proofs of your American edition, I have got to like them even better. I particularly like “Night Piece,” as I think I wrote you, and I greatly approve of your leaving out the last line; I was not crazy about that “posthorn of the coach of romance.” “Evening” is awfully good, and your referring to Samain in “At the British Museum” amused me and pleased me, showing that we were thinking of the same things. But what in the name of Patience did you mean by leaving out “The Poplar?” Man alive, it is one of your best poems! Monro has been doing a little editing, hasn’t he? I think that the American edition, although it won’t be half so attractive, will represent you better than this does. I miss your “morsel left half cold on Caesar’s plate,” and I could weep over “The Poplar” not being there. However, it is a pleasure to know that the books will not be exactly the same, although I think this one is a triumph of book making as well as a very attractive collection, only the whole of you is none to much for me.

I do hope to hear from Hilda soon about her poems, in answer to my last letter on the subject, and then we can go right to press. We are fearfully late now, and do not forget to cable about the Preface.
There is considerable discussion here about vers libre in all the papers. It is understood very little, and I think our preface is most important to explain it to the lay reader.

By way of making things peculiarly awkward, I have just received the poems from Lawrence which he says have been returned to him from Italy. I have not had time to go through them yet, but I do not see how we can take them anyway, as there is certainly not time to send them over to you, and get your opinion about them. It is a shame we did not get them before, for I have no doubt that there are some here that we should like better than “Resurrection.” But it cannot be helped now, I really think; we shall not be out until Autumn if this goes on. He has asked me to find a publisher for his poems, and I am to take them in to Ferris Greenslet on Monday. I want him to take them for the Autumn set of the New Poetry Series, if possible.

It is hard arranging all these things at a distance, and letters are particularly difficult, because you write in one mood, and I answer it in that mood, and the chance of its being the mood you receive it in are slight. The result is that sometimes you sound cross and depress me, and sometimes I undoubtedly sound the same way. We must just forget those things, and put it down to the difficulties of distance. I think the new Anthology will be a better book than the last, which is something.

postscript.p: Here is a little clipping from the “Chicago Tribune.” I suppose H.D. means a skit upon Hilda. I thought you might like to see it. Parodies are one side of success, you know.
